Oh, darn, I forgot.  Sorry.
So, texture filtering is set to 0604.  We don't expect this value.
Currently we support the lower value (4) being from 0 - 7.  This is the min value (used when sampling the texture to a smaller area.)
The upper value (6), we treat odd values as linear filtering, and even values as nearest.  We ignore any value like 6.  However, if we did support 6, it would still be nearest, but it would filter between the nearest two mipmap levels I guess.
Does this value vary when linear filtering is working / is not working?  Or is it always 0604 or etc. when things that ought to be filtered are drawn?
Maybe the PSP treats any none zero value in the upper slot as linear.

I've digged into this a little bit, and it seems to be an error caused the following cascade of events:
ViewingStatusController tries creating a new ViewingStatusService, which, in turn, tries creating a new ViewingStatus.
Movie does not have a TvShow show property, like Episode does, so it fails in this line, trying to access the TvShow show property of a Movie.
A solution (I think) would be handling the type of the video being saved (movie or episode) and, in the case of it being a Movie, do something (that I don't know) to create the ViewingStatus without accessing the TvShow show property.
Sorry for the messy explanation, hope the links clarify it a little!

Hi @JLau-cy apologies for the delayed response.
You do not have to call AWSCognitoIdentityCustomChallengeDetails.task.continueOnSuccessWith. You just need to set the result on AWSCognitoIdentityCustomChallengeDetails object. SDK will take care of the rest. When the custom auth completes you will get a call back on didCompleteStepWithError. If error object is nil, that means the step succeeded.

I played around with this, and I think I've narrowed it down to just the \r char. When HTML is parsing, it normalizes \r and \r\n into a single \n char, which affects the hashing. If I do a replace(/\r/g, '') on the script before hashing and printing into the HTML, it works correctly. Sorry for the confusion!

I agree that DISABLE_EXCEPTION_CATCHING doesn't really need 2 and can infer it from EXCEPTION_CATCHING_ALLOWED. But I'm not sure if we can remove it without breaking  up existing Makefiles and such. We can break backward compatibility if it's really necessary, but I'm not sure if this is an important enough reason to do it.
Having said that, I also agree this PR may not have enough traction. The first version of the PR also contained lines like
set_settings('INLINING_LIMIT') ;; this means 1

INLINING_LIMIT can take any numeric value, so only omitting 1 looked weird. But I later realized those lines were caused by my mistakes 4 years ago and they really meant set_settings('INLINING_LIMIT', 50) (See #13726 (comment) and #13726 (comment)) and removed them from this PR, which only leaves DISABLE_EXCEPTION_CATCHING. Anyway closing this then.

Well, fair point. I'd reported issues just like this myself.
The bitter truth is: you have to rely on your system package manager, and just keep /usr/local empty. The¬†best make uninstall is rm -rf /usr/local/*. The more permanent stuff you keep alive under /usr/local, the more PITA you'll have with it in the long run. (However, /usr/local shines in playground-style experiments.)
Worse; you can't trust package authors to do uninstall properly. That is another reason why package managers exist; so that we have this epic bug occur exactly once, and learn from the lesson. In that bug, an author rolled his own uninstall script, and made a fatal typo rm -rf /usr /lib/nvidia-current/xorg/xorg -- spot the extra space.
Sure, we'll fix this in Guake. But many more other projects won't. Many projects don't even offer make uninstall -- correctly delegating that function to package managers. I'm sorry that you had to have the adventure to figure this out, but the advice is: just don't make the habit to rely on it.
This package came from OpenWrt with no any changes and we'll keep it as close to upstream as possible to simplify future updates. Sorry.

well sorry @elyday but I think you are wrong
the result is just fine.
grouping means like nested "for each"
for each column1 value1
for each column2 value2
for each column3 value3
for each column4 value4
save sum of all column5 values where column1 = value1 and column2 = value2 and column3=value3 and column4 = value4
for result like yours you probably want to group by only three fields. meaning:
GROUP BY column, column2, column4
read about group by here for example
http://www.w3schools.com/sql/sql_groupby.asp

Sorry, I should clarify that this is caused by an unfortunate decision to exclude the ARM SDK components by default when VS installs the SDK.  This is supposed to be corrected at some point, but I'm not sure when.
The more serious issue (the one I was referring to above) is that you can't just use Add/Remove Programs to "Change" the SDK and add the missing ARM files.  You have to actually uninstall/reinstall.
This is intentional behaviour because we want to have brew edit edit a named file in the current working directory if it's present. We have users that rely on this workflow. Sorry!

I will elaborate on the reason I opened that issue. I've used go doc time and picked time.Tick() for a client connection handler that should free the timer after the client has been disconnected and I assumed that it will free it automatically. It was a rookie mistake and from now on I use go doc -all <pkg> | less, instead. If the function name was TickForever(), I might have given it more thought.
I was convinced that I am not the only one who made that mistake or just read convenience wrapper and did not read further. So I have searched GitHub and googled for code that uses time.Tick() and sure enough I found some cases.
Here is a list of examples, which I believe are problematic, since there is an option to stop or break the loop, yet the ticker cannot be freed:

https://github.com/golang/sys/blob/master/windows/svc/example/service.go#L23
https://github.com/Netflix/hal-9001/blob/master/hal/periodic.go#L134
https://github.com/pydio/cells/blob/master/common/service/utils.go#L28
https://github.com/izikaj/iziproxy/blob/master/server/tcp_handle_signals.go#L49
https://github.com/gocraft/health/blob/master/aggregator.go#L22
https://github.com/GoogleCloudPlatform/compute-image-tools/blob/master/daisy/step_create_instances.go#L54
https://github.com/rs/xstats/blob/master/statsd/statsd.go#L79
https://github.com/flynn/flynn/blob/master/controller/scheduler/discoverd.go#L32

Cases that are not problematic, since the executable will exit and the runtime will stop the timer eventually, but are still misused and leak resources:

https://github.com/cockroachdb/cockroach/blob/master/pkg/storage/client_raft_test.go#L1390 (do their leaktest even work?)
https://github.com/solo-io/go-utils/blob/master/testutils/helper/curl.go#L61
https://github.com/odeke-em/youtube-popular-bot/blob/master/cmd/youtube-popular-bot/main.go#L110
https://github.com/influxdata/influx-stress/blob/master/cmd/insert.go#L119

I've found those examples using Google search string: intext:"time.Tick(" ext:go site:github.com

I understand your frustration, but lots of people feeling a behaviour is correct, doesn't mean it is the right thing to do.
TypeScript rewriting module identifiers is a slippery slippery slope.  What has been expressed multiple times in this thread is that TypeScript is configurable to model the behaviour of other module resolvers and other build tools, not replace or implement them.
Just because TypeScript can be configured to resolve modules in flexible ways doesn't not mean that TypeScript emits "broken code".  Certain loaders and bundlers that mirror this configuration would work just fine.
If we were to be critical of anything, we could blame the team for naming the option something that might look like it fixes a problem it was never intended to fix, though the documentation for the option makes it clear that it does not change the emit.
Because a particular tool doesn't solve a problem you have doesn't always mean it is that tools fault.  It maybe you are just don't have all the tools you need to solve your problem.

I could have better stated the concept. The more proper term is factory pattern and in my world the concrete implementation is the entity, but this isn't canonical in the development world. It was proposed by the GoF way back in the day in the hallowed tome of 'Design Patterns' for some light reading. I usually follow the abstract factory pattern (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Abstract_factory_pattern) for something like this. The basic idea is to provide the ability to (in the abstract) support multiple datasets through a single common interface. So - drugbank initially since it's free, and whatever next. From the end user perspective to get the entity ou just say something like
Drug drug = new DrugFactory("drugbank"); // or whatever ArrayList<String> searchResults = drug.searchByName('Haldol'); //flexible and fun! 
And the factory supplies you the concrete class. With drug, I can use the same methods as with any other concrete drug class - and expect the same results. The key being here is that Drug is an interface which forms the contract - it outlines the public methods the concrete class supply as well as the return. The concrete class implements the interface and no troubles no bubbles. I'll stop here....

@seriousme Sorry I am late to the thread (and it's already been closed). If anything, the Algorithm Archive is closer to Numerical Recipes than Rosetta Code. I am fully aware both of these projects exist and are similar in scope to the Algorithm Archive; however, we are providing something new here that no other project provides (so far as I'm aware).
Differences from Rosetta Code:

This is fundamentally a book on algorithms, focusing on understanding the underlying algorithms. The goal here is to provide a reading experience that allows users to fully implement and understand every algorithm from the ground-up in the language of their choice. It is definitely not a collection of tasks for the community to complete.
The implementations provided here are also meant for understanding and we will always try to only merge code that can be understood completely. Sure, we are lacking the power to review certain languages, but I have no doubt people will come in to do just that.
We have the goal of providing a full curriculum for different areas of computer science, mathematics, physics, etc. This would mean that anyone wanting to learn the ropes in computational physics (for example) can read our volume on computational physics, and they should be able to fully understand that area of research.

Differences from Numerical Recipes:

First and foremost, our licensing for the code snippets is actually somewhat sane.
This text (in principle) has both a broader scope and expects less background knowledge from the reader. Obviously, we are not there yet on either of those goals, but I are doing what I can to get there.
This text is also (in principle) more of a modern take on the algorithms. Though NR has obviously been updated since 1986, it is showing it's age.

To be clear: I am not against either project. They are both wonderful resources. This book is targeted at a fundamentally different audience than NR (We want people who would watch a youtube video and think, "Oh man. I want to do that!" -- basically hobby programmers), but also attempts to provide clear descriptions of the algorithms so people don't need to collate papers and resources from other places.
The tagline, "A book on every algorithm in existence in every language possible" is not incorrect. I am sure with time it will become more obvious what the differences are because we are only just now getting started.
Let me know if you have any further questions here. I know that the scope seems similar in nature, but I can assure you we looked at Rosetta Code before starting this project.

Hi Matthew,
Thanks for reaching out ‚Äì sorry this took a few days to bubble up to the top after the long weekend.
We use the data that VS Code gathers to provide and improve the product.  For example, in the past, we‚Äôve used the data we collected to isolate several hard to track down sources of crashes and performance regressions.   VS Code may use the hashed MAC address to identify a machine over time.  For example, we may use the hashed MAC address to identify a particular machine experiencing an unusually high number of crashes (which would skew our crash result information).  You are right that we could correlate a machine across data streams, but that‚Äôs not how we use it -- we use the unique system information to connect things like crash reports with feature use.
When we first launched VS Code we didn‚Äôt allow people to opt out of this collection of data because it was a pre-release product and we were trying to understand if the product was actually useful and had the right mix of features.  As a fully released and supported product from Microsoft, we now let users opt out of providing data -- if users don‚Äôt want to provide us with data, then they can opt out but we really appreciate it when we do receive the telemetry as it helps improve the product for all.  That‚Äôs said, we want to ensure users have adequate control.
I‚Äôd be happy to chat with you on this issue and the points you raise.  I think the easiest way to do that is to connect on email/skype/hangout ‚Ä¶ I‚Äôm smcbreen@microsoft.com.
Sean

The flow should be something like this (text is imprecise and this is a very low-fi rough wireframe design-wise):

Some of this, such as the reboot button being a split dropdown like the system overview, could be deferred to another PR. But this PR should have much of the general flow in the wireframe.
Important parts:

Let people know what's up as soon as possible. They should expect that their system may need to be rebooted and that services might need to be restarted. We should have a quick and dirty check that gets this mostly correct, but might be wrong. Hence may. Having it all the time  (whenever updates are available) would be bad, however, as people will just ignore it. So it should be based on some sort of heuristics.
Show the updates as they happen. (We have this already, even in master.)
Provide feedback when the system is doing something, such as checking to see if services need restarting and/or the system needs rebooting. We currently do not do this in the PR. It's absolutely mandatory to have this step.
Have three states at the end:

Updated (and doesn't need intervention). In-page design, like in Cockpit currently.
Services need restarting. A dialog with a simple list of services that need to be restarted, with all checked by default.
System needs a reboot ‚Äî with a button to reboot the machine. In-page design, like in Cockpit currently.

Ideally with a split button like overview. But that can be a future PR.
Minimally, the action needs to exist, so a simple button should be enough.
We could do the reboot / ignore pattern, but switch ignore to manage services, which would then show the services need restarting dialog. But we'd need to keep the system needs rebooting state with an action button, perhaps in a banner or alert in the software page and in the overview. Or we could make it a top-level shell thing (in another PR).

Now that it is flat, properties won't be transferred when extracting which will mitigate this issue.

@arielb1
Sorry for not replying. I'm afraid I still don't quite follow you, so let me try and work it out. First off, I guess you meant to have impl<T>, like so, and probably Fn<(&'a u32,)>:
impl<T> Foo for Option<T> where
    for<'a> T: Fn<(&'a u32,)>,
    for<'a> <T as Fn<(&'a u32,)>>::Output: Sized
{}

// evaluate <Option<_> as Foo>
I'm not quite sure what the last line means, but if we were to follow the model of the original problem, we'd start with something to prove like for<'a> Option<&'a X>: Foo. "Opening" the for and matching this against the impl yields:
Option<$T> = Option<&'0 X>

and hence T = &'0 X. This suggests that we would translate the where clauses on the impl to:
for<'a> &'0 X: Fn<(&'a u32,)>
for<'a> <&'0 X as Fn<(&'a u32,)>>::Output: Sized

which we would could then cover back up as:
for<'a, 'b> &'b X: Fn<(&'a u32,)>
for<'a, 'b> <&'b X as Fn<(&'a u32,)>>::Output: Sized

This all seems...OK. Ah, wait, I guess your point is that we would need to normalize the <&'b X as Fn<(&'a u32,)>>::Output. I feel like we have issues normalizing under for binders still, right?

OK ... sorry guys, but I guess my mind was somewhere else earlier today and I really didn't take a look at what this actually does. Now that I look at it ... I'm rather confused - this can't possibly work.
_config_delimiters() doesn't have access to $rules - it's not a property, it's not passed by a parameter to the method and (thank God) it's not a global either.
And why is a method even needed for that? It's protected, so it's not accessible from outside the class unless you extend it. And that also doesn't make sense, because it's only called by the constructor here, where the whole thing should actually be.
Move those two if()s to the constructor and it's all OK.

This is incorrect behaviour, I'm afraid.
The charset parameter is only defined for documents of type text/*. That does not apply to application/x-www-form-urlencoded. Therefore, sending charset would be a specification violation.
Our behaviour is consistent with the W3C HTML5 specification, which says the following:

If the form element has an accept-charset attribute, let the selected character encoding be the result of picking an encoding for the form.
Otherwise, if the form element has no accept-charset attribute, but the document's character encoding is an ASCII-compatible character encoding, then that is the selected character encoding.
Otherwise, let the selected character encoding be UTF-8.

We can't do either of the first two things because we don't know what the document or form looks like, so we can only do the third. If the user wants a different behaviour (per the first two points) they are required to do it themselves.
I'm sorry we can't accept this, but this is one of those things that seems like it should be simple but is actually quite complex.

@smyrman Sorry, I did not realize your OP included an example. I was multitasking and so was not careful enough.
I think, as you are realizing, what started as a solution for tedious error handling is trying to become a general purpose construct.  It might be trying to do too much.  But I'll humor you and assume it makes sense to do this route. (Ironically, even though @networkimprov doesn't like this proposal, his comment helped me conceptualize what you are trying to do.)
If the break condition includes a variable comparison, it evaluates when the variable changes. If the condition contains a function call it is also evaluates on every assignment, every control structure condition evaluation and upon every return from a func call, but only once if the return is also an assignment or a control structure condition evaluation.
And if the condition is time consuming then you should restructure your code so that you do not use a time consuming condition with this construct. Instead, use an if statement where you want to evaluate it.
